methods.description: Associates an internal procedure with an ABL callback event. Return type:LOGICAL

parameters.name: callback-name
parameters.description: A quoted string or character expression representing the name of a callback. The callback-name is not case-sensitive. For a ProDataSet buffer object handle, this can be "BEFORE-FILL", "AFTER-FILL", "BEFORE-ROW-FILL", "AFTER-ROW-FILL", "ROW-CREATE", "ROW-DELETE", "ROW-UPDATE", "FIND-FAILED", or "SYNCHRONIZE". For a Procedure object handle, when calling a Web service, this can be either "REQUEST-HEADER" or "RESPONSE-HEADER". For a ProDataSet object handle, this can be "BEFORE-FILL" or "AFTER-FILL". For a Query object handle, this can be "OFF-END". You can also use the APPLY-CALLBACK( ) method to apply a callback procedure for an object.

parameters.name: internal-procedure
parameters.description: A quoted string or character expression representing the name of an internal procedure that resides within procedure-context.

parameters.name: procedure-context
parameters.description: A handle to a procedure that contains the internal procedure specified by internal-procedure. If not specified, THIS-PROCEDURE is used as the procedure context.

systemHandles.name: FILE-INFO
systemHandles.description: A handle to an operating system file.

attributes.name: FILE-CREATE-DATE
attributes.description: (Windows only) Indicates the date on which the specified file was created.

attributes.name: FILE-CREATE-TIME
attributes.description: (Windows only) Indicates the time when the specified file was created.

attributes.name: FILE-MOD-DATE
attributes.description: Indicates the last date the specified file was modified. This attribute is supported on all platforms.

attributes.name: FILE-MOD-TIME
attributes.description: Indicates the last time the specified file was modified. This attribute is supported on all platforms.

attributes.name: FILE-NAME
attributes.description: The name of the file associated with a handle. Returns the empty string for a Web service procedure. The FILE-NAME attribute of the COMPILER handle is maintained only for backward compatibility. Use theGET-FILE-NAME( ) method, instead. The FILE-NAME attribute of the COMPILER handle is the name of the source file from the preceding compilation. If no error occurred during the preceding compilation, FILE-NAME assumes the unknown value (?). For the PROFILER handle, FILE-NAME is the file into which the profiling data is written after the raw recorded data is analyzed. The file name must be set before data can be stored. The default value is the unknown value (?). The FILE-NAME attribute of the FILE-INFO or RCODE-INFO handle is the name of the file used by subsequent references to the handle. You can specify the filename with a.p,.r, or no extension. If you set FILE-NAME to a relative pathname, then the AVM searches thePROPATHto find the file. Otherwise, the AVM looks for the file specified by the absolute pathname. When used with FILE-INFO, the filename can contain Unicode characters. When used with RCODE-INFO, the filename cannot contain characters outside of the non-Unicode code page. For more information about Unicode and code pages, seeInternationalize ABL Applications. The FILE-NAME attribute of a procedure handle is the pathname of the procedure file that contains the procedure associated with the handle. If the procedure file is specified by the Startup Procedure (-p) parameter, then the attribute contains the full pathname of the file. Otherwise, it contains the pathname exactly as specified in the RUN statement that invoked it. The procedure can be local or remote. The FILE-NAME attribute of the COMPILER handle and procedure handle is read only.

attributes.name: FILE-SIZE
attributes.description: Indicates the size of the specified file. This attribute is supported on all platforms.

attributes.name: FILE-TYPE
attributes.description: A string of characters that indicate the type of file that is currently specified for theFILE-INFOhandle. The character string specifies two classes of file typesâone type per file from the first class and one or more types per file from the second class. The following table lists the file type characters from the first class of file types. The file is a member of an ABL library (procedure library (.pl) or archive file (.apl)). The following table lists the file type characters from the second class of file types.

attributes.name: FULL-PATHNAME
attributes.description: The absolute pathname of the file specified in the FILE-NAME attribute. The pathname can contain Unicode characters. SeeInternationalize ABL Applicationsfor more information about Unicode.

attributes.name: HANDLE
attributes.description: A handle to the object. You can store this value in a HANDLE variable. You can also use it to associate one widget with another widget or with a system handle. For example, you can assign the HANDLE value of the menu bar to the MENU-BAR attribute of a window, or you can make the window the current window by assigning its HANDLE value to the CURRENT-WINDOW handle. For query objects, the HANDLE attribute lets you acquire a query object for a static query, as shown in the following code:

attributes.name: INSTANTIATING-PROCEDURE
attributes.description: Returns the handle to the procedure in which an object was instantiated. When applied to a widget or an object handle, this attribute returns a handle. This handle is either valid or invalid, based on the state of the instantiating procedure. The instantiating procedure for a dynamically created object might no longer be running. In this case, the handle is invalid. In general, the INSTANTIATING-PROCEDURE attribute returns the procedure handle for the procedure in which the DEFINE or CREATE statement is executed. The following are the exceptions: Although this attribute applies to all widgets and handles, not all system handles are associated with an instantiating procedure and do not return a procedure handle. For these system handles, this attribute returns the unknown value (?). The following system handles always return the unknown value (?):

attributes.name: PATHNAME
attributes.description: The absolute or relative pathname of the file specified by the FILE-NAME attribute of the FILE-INFO Handle. If the FILE-NAME attribute specifies a simple filename or relative pathname, this attribute returns a relative pathname based on thePROPATH. Otherwise, it returns the absolute pathname specified in FILE-NAME. The pathname can contain Unicode characters. SeeInternationalize ABL Applicationsfor more information about Unicode.

attributes.name: TYPE
attributes.description: The type of a handle. The TYPE attribute returns the widget or handle type. Some examples are"WINDOW","FRAME","BUTTON","MENU","SAX-ATTRIBUTES","SAX-READER", and"SERVER". For application server and Web service handles, the TYPE attribute returns"SERVER". If a system handle (such as CURRENT-WINDOW or FOCUS) refers to a user interface widget, then the TYPE attribute returns the type of that widget. If a system handle (such as SESSION or CLIPBOARD) refers to an ABL status or system object, then the TYPE attribute value is"PSEUDO-WIDGET". For procedure handles and system handles that refer to procedures (such as THIS-PROCEDURE), the TYPE attribute returns"PROCEDURE". For an asynchronous request handle, the TYPE attribute returns"ASYNC-REQUEST". For the ProDataSet, data-relation, and data-source object handles, this attribute returns"DATASET","DATA-RELATION", and"DATA-SOURCE", respectively. For a server-socket handle, the TYPE attribute returns"SERVER-SOCKET", and for a socket handle, it returns"SOCKET". For the SOAP-fault and SOAP-fault-detail object handles, this attribute returns"SOAP-FAULT"and"SOAP-FAULT-DETAIL", respectively. For the SOAP-header and SOAP-header-entryref object handles, this attribute returns"SOAP-HEADER"and"SOAP-HEADER-ENTRYREF", respectively. For the X-document and X-noderef object handles, the TYPE attribute returns"X-DOCUMENT"and"X-NODEREF", respectively. For browse columns, the TYPE attribute returns"COMBO-BOX","FILL-IN", or"TOGGLE-BOX". If you specify the Browse Column Type (-browcoltype) startup parameter, then the TYPE attribute for browse columns returns"BROWSE-COLUMN"regardless of the actual column type.

systemHandles.name: COMPILER
systemHandles.description: A handle to information on a preceding COMPILE statement.

attributes.name: CLASS-TYPE
attributes.description: Returns the class type of the most recently compiled class definition (.cls) file. If the most recently compiled file was not a class definition file, this attribute returns the empty string ("").

attributes.name: ERROR
attributes.description: A compile-time or run-time error condition. The ERROR attribute corresponds to theERROR function. For the asynchronous request object handle, the ERROR attribute indicates that the ERROR condition was encountered during the processing of an application server or Web Server request. If the COMPLETE attribute is FALSE, the value of this attribute is the Unknown value (?). This attribute is set immediately before the associated event procedure or method is executed. For the COMPILER system handle, the ERROR attribute indicates whether an error occurred in the preceding compilation. If no error occurred in the preceding compilation, the value of ERROR is the Unknown value (?). For theProDataSet object handle,Temp-table object handle, andBuffer object handle, the ERROR attribute indicates whether an error occurred during a FILL or SAVE-ROW-CHANGES operation. For a ProDataSet object handle or a temp-table object handle, the ERROR attribute is reset to FALSE when one of the following methods removes the object's before-image records: The ERROR attribute is effective only if a before-table is NO-UNDO during a data source update. If the before-table is UNDO, the ERROR attribute is lost. For theBuffer object handle, this attribute causes the row to be backed out rather than merged with theMERGE-CHANGES( ) methodor theMERGE-ROW-CHANGES( ) method. This attribute is marshalled between the client and the application server. For the ERROR-STATUS system handle, the ERROR attribute indicates whether the ABL ERROR condition was raised in the most recent statement that used the NO-ERROR option. If no ERROR condition was raised in that statement, the value of the ERROR attribute is FALSE. The ERROR attribute is writeable for a ProDataSet object, a Temp-table object, and a Buffer object. You can set the ERROR attribute programmatically in order to manage the application response to errors. For example, you might set the ERROR attribute to FALSE in order to ignore all errors that might be returned for a statement using the NO-ERROR option. However, note that manually setting this attribute has no affect on ABL error management. Thus, if you set the ERROR attribute to TRUE, the AVM doesnotalso raise the ERROR condition.

attributes.name: ERROR-COLUMN
attributes.description: The character position at which a compiler error occurred. If no error occurred in the preceding compilation, the value of ERROR-COLUMN is the Unknown value (?).

attributes.name: ERROR-ROW
attributes.description: The line number at which a compiler error occurred. If no error occurred in the preceding compilation, the value of ERROR-ROW is the Unknown value (?).

attributes.name: FILE-NAME
attributes.description: The name of the file associated with a handle. Returns the empty string for a Web service procedure. The FILE-NAME attribute of the COMPILER handle is maintained only for backward compatibility. Use theGET-FILE-NAME( ) method, instead. The FILE-NAME attribute of the COMPILER handle is the name of the source file from the preceding compilation. If no error occurred during the preceding compilation, FILE-NAME assumes the unknown value (?). For the PROFILER handle, FILE-NAME is the file into which the profiling data is written after the raw recorded data is analyzed. The file name must be set before data can be stored. The default value is the unknown value (?). The FILE-NAME attribute of the FILE-INFO or RCODE-INFO handle is the name of the file used by subsequent references to the handle. You can specify the filename with a.p,.r, or no extension. If you set FILE-NAME to a relative pathname, then the AVM searches thePROPATHto find the file. Otherwise, the AVM looks for the file specified by the absolute pathname. When used with FILE-INFO, the filename can contain Unicode characters. When used with RCODE-INFO, the filename cannot contain characters outside of the non-Unicode code page. For more information about Unicode and code pages, seeInternationalize ABL Applications. The FILE-NAME attribute of a procedure handle is the pathname of the procedure file that contains the procedure associated with the handle. If the procedure file is specified by the Startup Procedure (-p) parameter, then the attribute contains the full pathname of the file. Otherwise, it contains the pathname exactly as specified in the RUN statement that invoked it. The procedure can be local or remote. The FILE-NAME attribute of the COMPILER handle and procedure handle is read only.

attributes.name: FILE-OFFSET
attributes.description: The character offset in the source file in which a Compiler error occurred. If no error occurred in the preceding compilation, the value of FILE-OFFSET is the Unknown value (?).

attributes.name: HANDLE
attributes.description: A handle to the object. You can store this value in a HANDLE variable. You can also use it to associate one widget with another widget or with a system handle. For example, you can assign the HANDLE value of the menu bar to the MENU-BAR attribute of a window, or you can make the window the current window by assigning its HANDLE value to the CURRENT-WINDOW handle. For query objects, the HANDLE attribute lets you acquire a query object for a static query, as shown in the following code:

attributes.name: INSTANTIATING-PROCEDURE
attributes.description: Returns the handle to the procedure in which an object was instantiated. When applied to a widget or an object handle, this attribute returns a handle. This handle is either valid or invalid, based on the state of the instantiating procedure. The instantiating procedure for a dynamically created object might no longer be running. In this case, the handle is invalid. In general, the INSTANTIATING-PROCEDURE attribute returns the procedure handle for the procedure in which the DEFINE or CREATE statement is executed. The following are the exceptions: Although this attribute applies to all widgets and handles, not all system handles are associated with an instantiating procedure and do not return a procedure handle. For these system handles, this attribute returns the unknown value (?). The following system handles always return the unknown value (?):

attributes.name: MULTI-COMPILE
attributes.description: Specifies whether ABL compiles all class definition files in the inherited class hierarchy or only those class definition files for which a cached version is not found. When set to TRUE, ABL compiles only those class definition files in the inherited class hierarchy that are not found in the cache. ABL also caches any classes or interfaces it compiles to avoid recompiling them during the session. When set to FALSE, ABL compiles all class definition files in the inherited class hierarchy. ABL also clears the cache of any classes or interfaces compiled during the session. The default value is FALSE.

attributes.name: NUM-MESSAGES
attributes.description: The number of error messages currently available through the specified system handle. For the COMPILER system handle, this value represents the number of compilation errors detected during the preceding ABL source code compilation. For the ERROR-STATUS system handle, this value represents the number of messages returned for the ERROR condition raised in a statement run with the NO-ERROR option.

attributes.name: OPTIONS
attributes.description: Indicates the options enabled that control the behavior of the ABL compiler. The default value is the empty string ("") or the options specified by the-compileroptionsfilestartup parameter. See OPTIONS under theCOMPILE statemententry for a complete list of possible values.

attributes.name: STOPPED
attributes.description: Indicates whether the last compilation stopped prior to completion. If set to TRUE, theSTOPPEDattribute indicates that the user interrupted the compile withCTRL+CorCTRL+BREAK. Because this raises theSTOPcondition you must handle it with anON STOPblock orCATCHblock to look at the attribute.

attributes.name: TYPE
attributes.description: The type of a handle. The TYPE attribute returns the widget or handle type. Some examples are"WINDOW","FRAME","BUTTON","MENU","SAX-ATTRIBUTES","SAX-READER", and"SERVER". For application server and Web service handles, the TYPE attribute returns"SERVER". If a system handle (such as CURRENT-WINDOW or FOCUS) refers to a user interface widget, then the TYPE attribute returns the type of that widget. If a system handle (such as SESSION or CLIPBOARD) refers to an ABL status or system object, then the TYPE attribute value is"PSEUDO-WIDGET". For procedure handles and system handles that refer to procedures (such as THIS-PROCEDURE), the TYPE attribute returns"PROCEDURE". For an asynchronous request handle, the TYPE attribute returns"ASYNC-REQUEST". For the ProDataSet, data-relation, and data-source object handles, this attribute returns"DATASET","DATA-RELATION", and"DATA-SOURCE", respectively. For a server-socket handle, the TYPE attribute returns"SERVER-SOCKET", and for a socket handle, it returns"SOCKET". For the SOAP-fault and SOAP-fault-detail object handles, this attribute returns"SOAP-FAULT"and"SOAP-FAULT-DETAIL", respectively. For the SOAP-header and SOAP-header-entryref object handles, this attribute returns"SOAP-HEADER"and"SOAP-HEADER-ENTRYREF", respectively. For the X-document and X-noderef object handles, the TYPE attribute returns"X-DOCUMENT"and"X-NODEREF", respectively. For browse columns, the TYPE attribute returns"COMBO-BOX","FILL-IN", or"TOGGLE-BOX". If you specify the Browse Column Type (-browcoltype) startup parameter, then the TYPE attribute for browse columns returns"BROWSE-COLUMN"regardless of the actual column type.

attributes.name: WARNING
attributes.description: Indicates whether the last compilation produced warning messages. If the WARNING attribute is TRUE, there were warning messages from the last compilation.

methods.name: GET-COLUMN
methods.description: Returns the column number at which thenth message occurred during the preceding compilation. Return type:INTEGER

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: An integer expression, from 1 to the value of the NUM-MESSAGES attribute, that specifies the numeric occurrence of a compilation message. If the nth occurrence of a compilation message did not occur, the compiler issues a warning message at runtime.

methods.name: GET-ERROR-COLUMN
methods.description: Returns the listing column number at which thenth error occurred in the preceding ABL source code compilation. This method is supported only for backward compatibility. Use theGET-COLUMN( ) methodinstead. Return type:INTEGER

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: An integer expression, from 1 to the value of the NUM-MESSAGES attribute, that specifies the numeric occurrence of a compilation error. If the nth occurrence of a compilation error did not occur, this method returns the Unknown value (?).

methods.name: GET-ERROR-ROW
methods.description: Returns the listing line number at which thenth error occurred in the preceding ABL source code compilation. This method is supported only for backward compatibility. Use theGET-ROW( ) methodinstead. Return type:INTEGER

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: An integer expression, from 1 to the value of the NUM-MESSAGES attribute, that specifies the numeric occurrence of a compilation error.

methods.name: GET-FILE-NAME
methods.description: Returns the name of the source file associated with thenth error that occurred in the preceding ABL source code compilation. Return type:CHARACTER

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: An integer expression, from 1 to the value of the NUM-MESSAGES attribute, that specifies the numeric occurrence of a compilation error.

methods.name: GET-FILE-OFFSET
methods.description: Returns the character offset at which thenth error occurred in the associated source file during the preceding ABL source code compilation. Return type:INTEGER

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: An integer expression, from 1 to the value of the NUM-MESSAGES attribute, that specifies the numeric occurrence of a compilation error.

methods.name: GET-MESSAGE
methods.description: Returns the message associated with a specified error currently recorded by the specified system handle. Return type:CHARACTER

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: An integer expression, from 1 to the value of the NUM-MESSAGES attribute, that specifies the numeric occurrence of the error whose information you want to retrieve.

methods.name: GET-MESSAGE-TYPE
methods.description: Returns the message type associated with thenth message that occurred during the preceding compilation. Return type:INTEGER

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: An integer expression, from 1 to the value of the NUM-MESSAGES attribute, that specifies the numeric occurrence of a compilation message. If the nth occurrence of a compilation message did not occur, the compiler issues a warning message at runtime.

methods.name: GET-NUMBER
methods.description: Returns the error number associated with a specified error currently recorded by the specified system handle. Return type:INTEGER

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: An integer expression, from 1 to the value of the NUM-MESSAGES attribute, that specifies the numeric occurrence of the error whose information you want to retrieve.

methods.name: GET-ROW
methods.description: Returns the line number at which thenth message occurred during the preceding compilation. Return type:INTEGER

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: An integer expression, from 1 to the value of the NUM-MESSAGES attribute, that specifies the numeric occurrence of a compilation message. If the nth occurrence of a compilation message did not occur, the compiler issues a warning message at runtime.

systemHandles.name: WEB-CONTEXT
systemHandles.description: Provides access to information on the current connection to the Web server.

attributes.name: AUTO-DELETE-XML
attributes.description: Determines whether the X-document object handle is deleted on a new web request. The default is YES.

attributes.name: CONFIG-NAME
attributes.description: The WebSpeed service name. This method is called by theget-configWebSpeed API function. Intended for internal use only.

attributes.name: CURRENT-ENVIRONMENT
attributes.description: Returns a list of CGI environment variable settings and HTTP header information, and is used by theget-cgiWebSpeed API function. Intended for internal use only.

attributes.name: EXCLUSIVE-ID
attributes.description: The ID assigned to a state-aware cookie. Intended for internal use only.

attributes.name: FORM-INPUT
attributes.description: Returns raw HTTP form input that is less than 32K in size.

attributes.name: FORM-LONG-INPUT
attributes.description: Returns raw HTTP form input that is greater than 32K in size. The AVM performs no conversion on the data.

attributes.name: HANDLE
attributes.description: A handle to the object. You can store this value in a HANDLE variable. You can also use it to associate one widget with another widget or with a system handle. For example, you can assign the HANDLE value of the menu bar to the MENU-BAR attribute of a window, or you can make the window the current window by assigning its HANDLE value to the CURRENT-WINDOW handle. For query objects, the HANDLE attribute lets you acquire a query object for a static query, as shown in the following code:

attributes.name: HTML-CHARSET
attributes.description: (WebSpeed only) The ABL version (as opposed to the MIME version) of the code page name of a Web request. Set by ABL when a WebSpeed application incorporates dynamic code page support. The default is blank. Once the AVM sets HTML-CHARSET, each time a Web browser sends a Web request to the application:

attributes.name: HTML-END-OF-LINE
attributes.description:
Defaults to the newline character (ASCII 10; '~n'; '\n'). A null string value causes a NEWLINE character (not a null string) to be output. You might want to set this to "~n" (the NEWLINE character) or to the null string (to force the NEWLINE character). Depending on the other attribute values, using the NEWLINE rather than the
tag can result in more readable output when viewing document source in a browser.

attributes.name: HTML-END-OF-PAGE
attributes.description: Between stream pages, defaults to "<HR>". Output between stream pages to visually break up the sectioning caused by the PAGED or PAGE-SIZE options of the OUTPUT TO "WEB" statement. Does not affect the line count of any stream page.

attributes.name: HTML-FRAME-BEGIN
attributes.description: Before a SpeedScript frame, defaults to "<PRE>". Generally, if you change this value you must change the value of HTML-FRAME-END. Output only before the data row(s) for the current iteration of a DOWN frame, not to column headers (see also HTML-HEADER-BEGIN and HTML-HEADER-END). Applies to any side-labels displayed in the frame, whether or not the frame is a DOWN frame.

attributes.name: HTML-FRAME-END
attributes.description: After a SpeedScript frame, defaults to "". Generally, if you change this value you must change the value of HTML-FRAME-BEGIN. Output at the end of the data row(s) for the current iteration of a DOWN frame.

attributes.name: HTML-HEADER-BEGIN
attributes.description: Before the column headers of a SpeedScript frame, defaults to "<PRE>". Generally, if you change this value you must change the value of HTML-HEADER-END. Output at the beginning of the column header section of a DOWN frame.

attributes.name: HTML-HEADER-END
attributes.description: After the column headers of a SpeedScript frame, defaults to "". Generally, if you change this value you must change the value of HTML-HEADER-BEGIN. Output at the end of the column header section of a DOWN frame.

attributes.name: HTML-TITLE-BEGIN
attributes.description: Before a SpeedScript frame title, Defaults to the null string (""), no text. Generally, if you change this value you must change the value of HTML-TITLE-END. Output before the frame's TITLE value. Setting to a color or bold tag might improve readability.

attributes.name: HTML-TITLE-END
attributes.description: After a SpeedScript frame title, defaults to the null string (""), no text. Generally, if you change this value you must change the value of HTML-TITLE-BEGIN. Output after the frame's TITLE value.

attributes.name: INSTANTIATING-PROCEDURE
attributes.description: Returns the handle to the procedure in which an object was instantiated. When applied to a widget or an object handle, this attribute returns a handle. This handle is either valid or invalid, based on the state of the instantiating procedure. The instantiating procedure for a dynamically created object might no longer be running. In this case, the handle is invalid. In general, the INSTANTIATING-PROCEDURE attribute returns the procedure handle for the procedure in which the DEFINE or CREATE statement is executed. The following are the exceptions: Although this attribute applies to all widgets and handles, not all system handles are associated with an instantiating procedure and do not return a procedure handle. For these system handles, this attribute returns the unknown value (?). The following system handles always return the unknown value (?):

attributes.name: IS-JSON
attributes.description: Returns whether a JSON string was posted to the transaction server. The AVM determines the value by checking if the content-type HTTP header is either "application/json" or "text/json".

attributes.name: IS-XML
attributes.description: Returns whether an XML document was posted to the transaction server.

attributes.name: SESSION-END
attributes.description: Sets the end of a logical WebSpeed session. Intended for internal use only.

attributes.name: TYPE
attributes.description: The type of a handle. The TYPE attribute returns the widget or handle type. Some examples are"WINDOW","FRAME","BUTTON","MENU","SAX-ATTRIBUTES","SAX-READER", and"SERVER". For application server and Web service handles, the TYPE attribute returns"SERVER". If a system handle (such as CURRENT-WINDOW or FOCUS) refers to a user interface widget, then the TYPE attribute returns the type of that widget. If a system handle (such as SESSION or CLIPBOARD) refers to an ABL status or system object, then the TYPE attribute value is"PSEUDO-WIDGET". For procedure handles and system handles that refer to procedures (such as THIS-PROCEDURE), the TYPE attribute returns"PROCEDURE". For an asynchronous request handle, the TYPE attribute returns"ASYNC-REQUEST". For the ProDataSet, data-relation, and data-source object handles, this attribute returns"DATASET","DATA-RELATION", and"DATA-SOURCE", respectively. For a server-socket handle, the TYPE attribute returns"SERVER-SOCKET", and for a socket handle, it returns"SOCKET". For the SOAP-fault and SOAP-fault-detail object handles, this attribute returns"SOAP-FAULT"and"SOAP-FAULT-DETAIL", respectively. For the SOAP-header and SOAP-header-entryref object handles, this attribute returns"SOAP-HEADER"and"SOAP-HEADER-ENTRYREF", respectively. For the X-document and X-noderef object handles, the TYPE attribute returns"X-DOCUMENT"and"X-NODEREF", respectively. For browse columns, the TYPE attribute returns"COMBO-BOX","FILL-IN", or"TOGGLE-BOX". If you specify the Browse Column Type (-browcoltype) startup parameter, then the TYPE attribute for browse columns returns"BROWSE-COLUMN"regardless of the actual column type.

attributes.name: VALIDATE-XML
attributes.description: Sets validation on parsing when an XML document is posted to the transaction server. The default is NO.

attributes.name: X-DOCUMENT
attributes.description: Contains the X-document object handle of an XML document posted to the transaction server or the Unknown value (?) if there isn't one.

attributes.name: XML-ENTITY-EXPANSION-LIMIT
attributes.description: (WebSpeed Only) Indicates the maximum number of entity substitutions the XML parser (either DOM or SAX) will permit in a XML document sent as a WebSpeed request. By limiting the number of entity substitutions, use of this attribute prevents recursive entities from consuming system resources. The default value is 50,000. The attribute's value must be equal to or greater than 0; setting the attribute to a negative value will result in a runtime error. If the attribute is set to the Unknown value (?), the feature is off. You can set this behavior globally by using the-entityExpansionLimitstartup parameter. The default value of the attribute is set by the startup parameter, but you can change the attribute as needed to override the behavior set by the startup parameter. See theStartup Command and Parameter Referencefor more information.

attributes.name: XML-SCHEMA-PATH
attributes.description: (WebSpeed Only) A delimiter-separated list of directory paths for the XML Document Type Definition (DTD) associated with a particular XML document in a WebSpeed environment. Searched if the XML document contains a relative path to the DTD. Almost identical to the SCHEMA-PATH attribute of the X-document and SAX-reader objects. Like SCHEMA-PATH, the pathnames can contain Unicode characters. SeeInternationalize ABL Applicationsfor more information about Unicode. For more information on SCHEMA-PATH, see the reference entry for theSCHEMA-PATH attribute.

attributes.name: XML-STRICT-ENTITY-RESOLUTION
attributes.description: (WebSpeed Only) Indicates whether or not the XML parser (DOM or SAX) will attempt to resolve an external entity if the entity is located outside of the directories in the XML-SCHEMA-PATH attribute of an XML document sent as a WebSpeed request. If XML-STRICT-ENTITY-RESOLUTION is TRUE, the parser will NOT attempt to resolve an external entity that is located outside of the directories in the XML-SCHEMA-PATH attribute of the WEB-CONTEXT system handle. If XML-STRICT-ENTITY-RESOLUTION is FALSE, the parser will attempt to resolve an external entity. Setting this attribute to TRUE can help prevent an external caller from gaining access to data located in directories not included in the XML-SCHEMA-PATH attribute. You can set this behavior globally by using the-strictEntityResolutionstartup parameter. The default value of the attribute is set by the startup parameter, but you can change the attribute as needed to override the behavior set by the startup parameter. See theStartup Command and Parameter Referencefor more information.

attributes.name: XML-SUPPRESS-NAMESPACE-PROCESSING
attributes.description: (WebSpeed Only) Specifies whether to suppress namespace processing. Almost identical to the SUPPRESS-NAMESPACE-PROCESSING attribute of the X-document handle. For more information on SUPPRESS-NAMESPACE-PROCESSING, see the reference entry for theSUPPRESS-NAMESPACE-PROCESSING attribute.

methods.name: GET-BINARY-DATA
methods.description: Returns a MEMPTR containing the binary data in the file specified in the form field. The AVM sets the size of the MEMPTR to match the size of the file. This method is called by theget-binary-dataWebSpeed API function. Intended for internal use only. Return type:MEMPTR

parameters.name: field-name
parameters.description: The name of the form field containing the name of the file posted in the web request received by the WebSpeed Agent.

methods.name: GET-CGI-LIST
methods.description: Gets the list of CGI environment variables. This method is called by theget-cgiWebSpeed API function. Intended for internal use only. Return type:CHARACTER

methods.name: GET-CGI-LONG-VALUE
methods.description: Returns a LONGCHAR value in either the code page specified in the HTML-CHARSET attribute, if that code page is valid for a LONGCHAR, or-cpinternal. Otherwise, it returns the Unknown value (?) and displays an error message. You can suppress this message by using NO-ERROR on the statement containing the method. This method is called by theget-cgi-longandget-long-valueWebSpeed API functions. Intended for internal use only. Return type:LONGCHAR

methods.name: GET-CGI-VALUE
methods.description: Gets the value of a specified CGI environment variable. This method is called by theget-cgiWebSpeed API function. Intended for internal use only. Return type:CHARACTER

methods.name: GET-CONFIG-VALUE
methods.description: Gets the value of parameters set in the WebSpeed configuration file. This method is called by theget-configWebSpeed API function. Intended for internal use only. Return type:CHARACTER

methods.name: INCREMENT-EXCLUSIVE-ID
methods.description: Gets the amount by which to increment the exclusive ID of a Web request for state-aware agents. Do not access this method. Return type:INTEGER

methods.name: URL-DECODE
methods.description: Returns a URL string to decode. This method is called by theurl-decodeWebSpeed API function. Intended for internal use only. Return type:CHARACTER

methods.name: URL-ENCODE
methods.description: Returns characters to encode. This method is called by theurl-encodeWebSpeed API function. Intended for internal use only. Return type:CHARACTER

systemHandles.name: DSLOG-MANAGER
systemHandles.description: A handle to logging settings for the DataServers in the current session. The DataServers use a separate log file which you can specify with the DataServer Logging (-dslog) startup parameter. The default filename isdataserv.lg.

attributes.name: DB-CONTEXT
attributes.description: Returns the logical database to which the DSLOG-MANAGER system handle currently applies. Valid values are any valid, connected logical name or alias for a database of a supported database type. The default value is the Unknown value (?). If you set DB-CONTEXT to an alias, it returns the logical name of the database currently assigned to that alias. Each DataServer connection is a separate entity for which you can specify different logging settings. You use this attribute at run time to specify the DataServer connection with which you are working. You must set DB-CONTEXT before accessing any other attribute or method of the DSLOG-MANAGER system handle. If you set DB-CONTEXT to the Unknown value (?), you cannot access DSLOG-MANAGER until you reset DB-CONTEXT to a valid logical database name or alias. When the database specified in DB-CONTEXT is disconnected, the client automatically sets DB-CONTEXT to the Unknown value (?). The following statements show how you can set this attribute:

attributes.name: ENTRY-TYPES-LIST
attributes.description: Returns a character string containing a comma-separated list of all valid entry types for the current OpenEdge environment. For DataServer server logging, the string contains the valid entry types against the logical database specified by theDB-CONTEXT attribute.

attributes.name: HANDLE
attributes.description: A handle to the object. You can store this value in a HANDLE variable. You can also use it to associate one widget with another widget or with a system handle. For example, you can assign the HANDLE value of the menu bar to the MENU-BAR attribute of a window, or you can make the window the current window by assigning its HANDLE value to the CURRENT-WINDOW handle. For query objects, the HANDLE attribute lets you acquire a query object for a static query, as shown in the following code:

attributes.name: INSTANTIATING-PROCEDURE
attributes.description: Returns the handle to the procedure in which an object was instantiated. When applied to a widget or an object handle, this attribute returns a handle. This handle is either valid or invalid, based on the state of the instantiating procedure. The instantiating procedure for a dynamically created object might no longer be running. In this case, the handle is invalid. In general, the INSTANTIATING-PROCEDURE attribute returns the procedure handle for the procedure in which the DEFINE or CREATE statement is executed. The following are the exceptions: Although this attribute applies to all widgets and handles, not all system handles are associated with an instantiating procedure and do not return a procedure handle. For these system handles, this attribute returns the unknown value (?). The following system handles always return the unknown value (?):

attributes.name: LOG-ENTRY-TYPES
attributes.description: A comma-separated list of one or more types of log entries to write to the log file. Use theLOG-ENTRY-TYPESattribute to specify one or more types of log entries to write to the log file. For an OpenEdge client, the Client Logging (-clientlog) startup parameter or theLOG-MANAGERsystem handle'sLOGFILE-NAME attributespecifies the log file. For a DataServer server, the DataServer Logging (-dslog) startup parameter specifies the log file. TheLOG-ENTRY-TYPESattribute corresponds to the Log Entry Types (-logentrytypes) startup parameter. By default, the logging level you specify using theLOGGING-LEVEL attributeor the Logging Level (-logginglevel) startup parameter applies to all log entry types specified. However, you can specify a different logging level for each entry type by assigning a character expression as follows:

attributes.name: LOG-THRESHOLD
attributes.description: The file size threshold of log files. When the current log file becomes equal to or greater than the specified size, the AVM renames and saves the log file and creates a new log file. Valid values are: The AVM names log files controlled by either theDSLOG-MANAGERorLOG-MANAGERsystem handles based on a sequence number using the following format:

attributes.name: LOGFILE-NAME
attributes.description: The name of log file OpenEdge uses to log messages and ABL stack trace information. If the filename you supply is a relative pathname, then a file is accessed relative to the current working directory. If the filename is an absolute pathname, then the specified file is accessed. In Windows, the pathname cannot contain characters outside of the non-Unicode code page. SeeInternationalize ABL Applicationsfor more information about Unicode and code pages. When the specified log file is open, thisLOG-MANAGERattribute is read-only. This attribute is always read-only for theDSLOG-MANAGERsystem handle. For theLOG-MANAGERsystem handle, theLOGFILE-NAMEattribute corresponds to the Client Logging (-clientlog) startup parameter. For theDSLOG-MANAGERsystem handle, this attribute corresponds to the DataServer Logging (-dslog) startup parameter when the client is self-service or client/server using ProBroker. Use theLOG-ENTRY-TYPES attributeor the Log Entry Types (-logentrytypes) startup parameter to specify one or more types of log entries you want to write to the log file. Use theLOGGING-LEVEL attributeor the Logging Level (-logginglevel) startup parameter to specify a general level at which log entries are written to the log file. For more information about the Client Logging (-clientlog), DataServer Logging (-dslog), Log Entry Types (-logentrytypes), and Logging Level (-logginglevel) startup parameters, seeStartup Command and Parameter Reference,Use the Microsoft SQL Data Server, andTroubleshoot ABL Applications.

attributes.name: LOGGING-LEVEL
attributes.description: The level at which log entries are written to the log file. Use the LOGGING-LEVEL attribute to specify the level at which log entries are written to the log file. For an OpenEdge client, the Client Logging (-clientlog) startup parameter or the LOG-MANAGER system handle'sLOGFILE-NAME attributespecifies the log file. For a DataServer server, the DataServer Logging (-dslog) startup parameter specifies the log file. Each logging level specifies a different amount of information. There are five logging levels: By default, the logging level you specify applies to all log entry types. However, you can specify a different logging level for individual log entry types with theLOG-ENTRY-TYPES attributeor the Log Entry Types (-logentrytypes) startup parameter. The higher logging levels include the log information from the lower logging levels, in addition to the information logged at that level. The LOGGING-LEVEL attribute corresponds to the Logging Level (-logginglevel) startup parameter. For more information about the Client Logging (-clientlog), DataServer Logging (-dslog), Log Entry Types (-logentrytypes), or Logging Level (-logginglevel) startup parameters, seeStartup Command and Parameter Reference,Use the Microsoft SQL Data Server,Use the Oracle Data Server, andTroubleshoot ABL Applications.

attributes.name: NUM-LOG-FILES
attributes.description: The number of rolled over log files to keep on disk at any one time, for ABL session, including the current log file. Valid values are: TheNUM-LOG-FILESattribute corresponds to the Number of Log Files to Keep (-numlogfiles) startup parameter. For ABL clients, use theLOG-THRESHOLD attributeof theLOG-MANAGERor the Log Threshold (-logthreshold) startup parameter to specify the file size at which OpenEdge rolls over (renames and saves) log files. For DataServers, use the Log Threshold (-logthreshold) startup parameter to specify the file size at which the DataServer context will roll over (renames and saves) its log files when using self-service clients or ProBroker. For more information about the Number of Log Files to Keep (-numlogfiles) and Log Threshold (-logthreshold) startup parameters, seeStartup Command and Parameter Reference,Use the Microsoft SQL Data Server, andTroubleshoot ABL Applications.

attributes.name: TYPE
attributes.description: The type of a handle. The TYPE attribute returns the widget or handle type. Some examples are"WINDOW","FRAME","BUTTON","MENU","SAX-ATTRIBUTES","SAX-READER", and"SERVER". For application server and Web service handles, the TYPE attribute returns"SERVER". If a system handle (such as CURRENT-WINDOW or FOCUS) refers to a user interface widget, then the TYPE attribute returns the type of that widget. If a system handle (such as SESSION or CLIPBOARD) refers to an ABL status or system object, then the TYPE attribute value is"PSEUDO-WIDGET". For procedure handles and system handles that refer to procedures (such as THIS-PROCEDURE), the TYPE attribute returns"PROCEDURE". For an asynchronous request handle, the TYPE attribute returns"ASYNC-REQUEST". For the ProDataSet, data-relation, and data-source object handles, this attribute returns"DATASET","DATA-RELATION", and"DATA-SOURCE", respectively. For a server-socket handle, the TYPE attribute returns"SERVER-SOCKET", and for a socket handle, it returns"SOCKET". For the SOAP-fault and SOAP-fault-detail object handles, this attribute returns"SOAP-FAULT"and"SOAP-FAULT-DETAIL", respectively. For the SOAP-header and SOAP-header-entryref object handles, this attribute returns"SOAP-HEADER"and"SOAP-HEADER-ENTRYREF", respectively. For the X-document and X-noderef object handles, the TYPE attribute returns"X-DOCUMENT"and"X-NODEREF", respectively. For browse columns, the TYPE attribute returns"COMBO-BOX","FILL-IN", or"TOGGLE-BOX". If you specify the Browse Column Type (-browcoltype) startup parameter, then the TYPE attribute for browse columns returns"BROWSE-COLUMN"regardless of the actual column type.

methods.name: CLEAR-LOG
methods.description: Clears all messages existing in the current client log file and leaves the file open for writing. Return type:LOGICAL

methods.name: WRITE-MESSAGE
methods.description: Writes a user message to the current log file. For an interactive or batch client, the WRITE-MESSAGE(Â ) method writes the log entries to the log file specified by theLOGFILE-NAME attributeor the Client Logging (-clientlog) startup parameter. For application servers, the WRITE-MESSAGE(Â ) method writes the log entries to the server log file. For DataServers, the WRITE-MESSAGE(Â ) method writes the log entries to the log file specified by the DataServer Logging (-dslog) startup parameter. Return type:LOGICAL

parameters.name: msg-exp
parameters.description: A character expression or variable representing the message to write to the log file.

parameters.name: subsys-expr
parameters.description: A character expression representing the subsystem identifier to write to the log file. The default is "APPL". You can provide your own subsystem identifier. The subsystem identifier has a character limit 10 characters, and is padded to 10 characters. If you provide a subsystem identifier longer than 10 characters, WRITE-MESSAGE( ) writes only the first 10 characters.

systemHandles.name: LOG-MANAGER
systemHandles.description: A handle to logging settings for the current ABL session.

attributes.name: ENTRY-TYPES-LIST
attributes.description: Returns a character string containing a comma-separated list of all valid entry types for the current OpenEdge environment. For DataServer server logging, the string contains the valid entry types against the logical database specified by theDB-CONTEXT attribute.

attributes.name: HANDLE
attributes.description: A handle to the object. You can store this value in a HANDLE variable. You can also use it to associate one widget with another widget or with a system handle. For example, you can assign the HANDLE value of the menu bar to the MENU-BAR attribute of a window, or you can make the window the current window by assigning its HANDLE value to the CURRENT-WINDOW handle. For query objects, the HANDLE attribute lets you acquire a query object for a static query, as shown in the following code:

attributes.name: INSTANTIATING-PROCEDURE
attributes.description: Returns the handle to the procedure in which an object was instantiated. When applied to a widget or an object handle, this attribute returns a handle. This handle is either valid or invalid, based on the state of the instantiating procedure. The instantiating procedure for a dynamically created object might no longer be running. In this case, the handle is invalid. In general, the INSTANTIATING-PROCEDURE attribute returns the procedure handle for the procedure in which the DEFINE or CREATE statement is executed. The following are the exceptions: Although this attribute applies to all widgets and handles, not all system handles are associated with an instantiating procedure and do not return a procedure handle. For these system handles, this attribute returns the unknown value (?). The following system handles always return the unknown value (?):

attributes.name: LOG-ENTRY-TYPES
attributes.description: A comma-separated list of one or more types of log entries to write to the log file. Use theLOG-ENTRY-TYPESattribute to specify one or more types of log entries to write to the log file. For an OpenEdge client, the Client Logging (-clientlog) startup parameter or theLOG-MANAGERsystem handle'sLOGFILE-NAME attributespecifies the log file. For a DataServer server, the DataServer Logging (-dslog) startup parameter specifies the log file. TheLOG-ENTRY-TYPESattribute corresponds to the Log Entry Types (-logentrytypes) startup parameter. By default, the logging level you specify using theLOGGING-LEVEL attributeor the Logging Level (-logginglevel) startup parameter applies to all log entry types specified. However, you can specify a different logging level for each entry type by assigning a character expression as follows:

attributes.name: LOGFILE-NAME
attributes.description: The name of log file OpenEdge uses to log messages and ABL stack trace information. If the filename you supply is a relative pathname, then a file is accessed relative to the current working directory. If the filename is an absolute pathname, then the specified file is accessed. In Windows, the pathname cannot contain characters outside of the non-Unicode code page. SeeInternationalize ABL Applicationsfor more information about Unicode and code pages. When the specified log file is open, thisLOG-MANAGERattribute is read-only. This attribute is always read-only for theDSLOG-MANAGERsystem handle. For theLOG-MANAGERsystem handle, theLOGFILE-NAMEattribute corresponds to the Client Logging (-clientlog) startup parameter. For theDSLOG-MANAGERsystem handle, this attribute corresponds to the DataServer Logging (-dslog) startup parameter when the client is self-service or client/server using ProBroker. Use theLOG-ENTRY-TYPES attributeor the Log Entry Types (-logentrytypes) startup parameter to specify one or more types of log entries you want to write to the log file. Use theLOGGING-LEVEL attributeor the Logging Level (-logginglevel) startup parameter to specify a general level at which log entries are written to the log file. For more information about the Client Logging (-clientlog), DataServer Logging (-dslog), Log Entry Types (-logentrytypes), and Logging Level (-logginglevel) startup parameters, seeStartup Command and Parameter Reference,Use the Microsoft SQL Data Server, andTroubleshoot ABL Applications.

attributes.name: LOGGING-LEVEL

For an OpenEdge client, the Client Logging (-clientlog) startup parameter or the LOG-MANAGER system handle'sLOGFILE-NAME attributespecifies the log file. For a DataServer server, the DataServer Logging (-dslog) startup parameter specifies the log file. Each logging level specifies a different amount of information. There are five logging levels: By default, the logging level you specify applies to all log entry types. However, you can specify a different logging level for individual log entry types with theLOG-ENTRY-TYPES attributeor the Log Entry Types (-logentrytypes) startup parameter. The higher logging levels include the log information from the lower logging levels, in addition to the information logged at that level. The LOGGING-LEVEL attribute corresponds to the Logging Level (-logginglevel) startup parameter. For more information about the Client Logging (-clientlog), DataServer Logging (-dslog), Log Entry Types (-logentrytypes), or Logging Level (-logginglevel) startup parameters, seeStartup Command and Parameter Reference,Use the Microsoft SQL Data Server,Use the Oracle Data Server, andTroubleshoot ABL Applications.

attributes.name: LOG-THRESHOLD
attributes.description: The file size threshold of log files.
